newsitem.title: DUBAI: UAE banks to apply Internat'l Accounting Standards.
newsitem.headline: UAE banks to apply Internat'l Accounting Standards.

text.p: The Central Bank governor said on Monday banks in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) will soon have to base their accounts on International Accounting Standards.

Sultan bin Nasser al-Suweidi told an Islamic banking forum this was needed to give investors a chance to chose where to put surplus funds by comparing risk levels based on the same disclosure requirements.
"Disclosure based on similar foundations is paramount to comparing these risk levels," he said.

"Therefore, all UAE financial institutions will, in the near future, be required to base their accounting systems and disclosure statements on the basis of International Accounting Standards," he added.

Earlier, Suweidi told a news conference on the sidelines of the meeting the central bank had received several licensing requests from a host of banks, including conventional and Islamic institutions. But he said no decision had been made yet on granting licences.
Suweidi said he did not believe there was congestion in the UAE banking sector that could prompt the country to take action, such as preventing new banks from opening.
"In a free system, there is nothing called a banking glut," he said.
There are 27 foreign banks, 15 representative offices and 19 local banks operating in the UAE.
Some analysts have suggested that the UAE, like its Gulf Arab neighbours, is over-banked and some banks should merge.
